level1: All lands are either republics or principalities. A principality is ruled by a prince. A republic lets people vote.
level2: States come in two kinds: republics where citizens vote, and principalities where a prince is in charge.
level3: Every state is either a republic—shared power—or a principality, ruled by one person.
level4: All states that have held dominion over men are either republics or principalities.

level1: A prince can get land from his family or take new land. New land is harder to keep.
level2: Principalities are hereditary (passed down) or new (just captured). New ones are tricky.
level3: Principalities may be hereditary, long held by one bloodline, or brand-new, seized by force or fortune.
level4: Principalities are either hereditary, in which the family has been long established, or they are new.

level1: If your dad was prince, people already like you. Just don't change big rules.
level2: Inherited states are easier: keep old customs, don't make waves, and most subjects accept you.
level3: Hereditary states pose fewer difficulties; ancient customs and familiar rule keep the populace content.
level4: In hereditary states the prince has fewer difficulties, for it is sufficient not to transgress the customs of his ancestors.

level1: New land means new problems. People hoped life would improve. When it doesn't, they get mad.
level2: New principalities bring trouble: people swapped rulers expecting better lives; when taxes or soldiers arrive, they feel cheated.
level3: New principalities breed discontent: subjects welcomed change, then discover fresh burdens and regret their choice.
level4: In new principalities men willingly change their rulers, hoping to better themselves, and this hope induces them to take up arms.

level1: King Louis took Milan fast, but lost it fast. People let him in, then kicked him out.
level2: King Louis XII captured Milan overnight and lost it just as quickly; the same citizens who opened the gates later drove him out.
level3: Louis XII seized Milan with ease yet lost it at once, for the inhabitants who had admitted him soon revolted under new impositions.
level4: Louis the Twelfth, King of France, quickly occupied Milan, and as quickly lost it; the first time it only needed Lodovico's own forces.

level1: Go live in the new land. Fix problems fast. Send friends to live there too.
level2: The prince should reside in the new state, send loyal colonists, and protect weaker neighbors while weakening stronger ones.
level3: To hold new possessions the prince must live there, plant loyal colonies, and become protector of lesser powers while checking greater ones.
level4: The prince should go to live there, send colonies, and become the defender of the weaker neighbors while weakening the more powerful.

level1: Don't hire other people's armies. They cost a lot and might turn on you.
level2: Avoid foreign auxiliaries: they are expensive, unreliable, and may desert or betray you at the critical moment.
level3: Employing foreign troops is perilous; they drain treasure, owe no loyalty, and often flee or conspire against their employer.
level4: Auxiliary arms are useless and dangerous; if they lose you are undone, if they win you are left their prisoner.

level1: Free cities hate princes. Let them keep rules but pay you, or knock them down.
level2: Cities accustomed to freedom resent princes; let them keep their laws but pay tribute, or destroy them so liberty is forgotten.
level3: Free cities are hostile to princely rule; permit self-government under tribute, or raze them so the memory of freedom fades.
level4: States accustomed to live in freedom must be destroyed, or else held by permitting them to live under their own laws, drawing a tribute.

level1: Some princes build their own land. They need a chance and smart plans.
level2: Some princes found entirely new states; they require opportunity and outstanding ability to establish lasting rule.
level3: Founders of wholly new principalities need both favourable circumstance and remarkable talent to create enduring power.
level4: Let no one be surprised if, in speaking of entirely new principalities, I adduce the highest examples, for men almost always walk in paths beaten by others.

level1: Moses, Cyrus, Romulus, and Theseus all got a chance and used it well.
level2: Moses, Cyrus, Romulus, and Theseus seized their moment and displayed extraordinary ability to build new realms.
level3: Moses, Cyrus, Romulus, and Theseus exemplify men who, given opportunity, wielded exceptional skill to forge new states.
level4: Moses, Cyrus, Romulus, and Theseus, though they owed nothing to fortune but opportunity, which gave them the matter to mould.

level1: They made new rules. People were mad at first, then glad.
level2: They introduced new orders; initially hated, later revered once success was secured.
level3: They established novel institutions; early resistance turned to admiration after victory.
level4: They introduced new orders, which had the enmity of all those who profited by the old order and only lukewarm defenders among those who would profit by the new.

level1: If you start something new, be strong and fast. Weak people lose.
level2: Innovators must act swiftly and forcefully; half-measures invite ruin.
level3: New institutions demand decisive action; hesitation emboldens enemies and discourages allies.
level4: It is necessary, if we desire to discuss this matter thoroughly, to inquire whether these innovators can rely on themselves or have to depend on others.

level1: Armed prophets win. Unarmed prophets lose.
level2: Prophets who carry arms succeed; those who rely only on words are destroyed when belief fades.
level3: Armed prophets conquer; unarmed ones fall once the crowd no longer believes.
level4: All armed prophets have conquered, and the unarmed ones have been destroyed.

level1: Savonarola talked, but had no army. People stopped believing and he died.
level2: Savonarola preached reform without soldiers; when faith vanished he was ruined.
level3: Savonarola's example shows that moral authority without force collapses when popular belief evaporates.
level4: This happened in our own day to Fra Girolamo Savonarola, who was ruined with his new order of things immediately the multitude believed in him no longer.

level1: Hiero of Syracuse started as a normal guy, then became prince by being smart and strong.
level2: Hiero of Syracuse rose from private citizen to prince through merit and strength, founding a lasting state.
level3: Hiero exemplifies the private citizen who, by ability and fortune, became prince and secured his rule.
level4: Hiero the Syracusan, though he had to eliminate the old military and create a new one, abolished the old and organized the new.

level1: Some princes get land as a gift. They keep it only if they are smart and strong.
level2: Princes who receive states as gifts must still display ability; otherwise the gift is quickly lost.
level3: States bestowed by favor require the recipient to prove capable, or the gift becomes a trap.
level4: Those who solely by good fortune become princes from being private citizens have little trouble in rising, but much in keeping atop.

level1: Francesco Sforza used his own army and kept Milan. Cesare used his dad's army and lost everything.
level2: Francesco Sforza, relying on his own troops, held Milan securely; Cesare Borgia, depending on others, lost his state.
level3: Sforza's self-reliance secured Milan, whereas Borgia's dependence on external power left him vulnerable.
level4: Francesco Sforza, by proper means and with great ability, from being a private person rose to be Duke of Milan; Cesare Borgia, called by the people Duke Valentino, acquired his state during the ascendancy of his father, and on its decline he lost it.

level1: Cesare did many smart things, but when his dad died and he got sick, everything fell apart.
level2: Despite clever plans, Cesare's state collapsed when his father died and illness struck at the critical moment.
level3: Cesare's preparations were sound, yet the death of Alexander VI and his own sickness undid him.
level4: Cesare Borgia had laid good foundations, but the death of Alexander and his own illness frustrated his designs.

level1: Agathocles became king by killing leaders in one big meeting. Cruel, but it worked.
level2: Agathocles seized power by murdering senators and rich citizens in a single morning; cruelty secured his throne.
level3: Agathocles' brutal purge of the senate and wealthy citizens in one stroke allowed him to hold Syracuse.
level4: Agathocles the Sicilian, one morning assembled the people and senate of Syracuse as if he had to discuss things relating to the Republic, and at a given signal the soldiers killed all the senators and the richest of the citizens.

level1: Oliverotto tricked his uncle, had him killed at dinner, and took the city.
level2: Oliverotto lured his uncle and leading citizens to a banquet, then had them slaughtered and seized power.
level3: Oliverotto's banquet ambush eliminated the old guard and made him prince of Fermo overnight.
level4: Oliverotto da Fermo, having invited Giovanni Fogliani and the chiefs of Fermo to a solemn banquet, caused them to be assassinated, and thus made himself prince of the town.
